title-group.article-title: Impact of indocyanine green fluorescence angiography on esophagogastric anastomotic leakage after Ivor Lewis esophagectomy

contrib-group.aff: 1https://ror.org/01hq89f96grid.42399.350000 0004 0593 7118Esophagogastric Surgery Unit, Haut L’Evêque Hospital, CHU Bordeaux, France
2https://ror.org/01hq89f96grid.42399.350000 0004 0593 7118Thoracic Surgery Unit, Haut L’Evêque Hospital, CHU Bordeaux, France

sec.title: Purpose
sec.p: Esophagectomy for esophageal cancer involves high morbimortality when anastomotic leakage occurs. Optimal perfusion of the gastric tube can be assessed by indocyanine green fluorescence-angiography (ICG-FA). We evaluated whether locating the anastomosis in a zone enhanced within 60 s after ICG-FA injection reduced severe anastomotic leakage (Stage 2 or 3) within 30 days after esophagectomy.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: ICG-FA was assessed in 69 patients and compared to 122 control patients undergoing minimally invasive Ivor Lewis esophagectomy. Whenever possible, the anastomosis was placed on gastric tissue enhanced within 60 s after ICG-FA injection, with resection of the gastric tip if needed.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Severe anastomotic leakage occurred in 8.4% of cases, with 6 cases of anastomotic leakage (8.7%) in the ICG-FA group and 10 (8.2%) in the non-ICG-FA group (p = 1.000). There was no difference in postoperative outcomes between both groups, the main complications being pulmonary. ICG-FA enhancement level at 60 s was below the gastric tip in 33.8% of cases, with lowering of the anastomotic site in 18% of cases and resection of the gastric tip in 23% of cases. Overall, use of ICG-FA changed the surgical management in 29.9% of patients, with 2 patients presenting with anastomotic leakage.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Our results were not statistically significant, possibly due to a lack of power. There was no trend indicating a decrease in anastomotic leakage using our ICG-FA method, therefore other studies must help determine an optimal quantitative ICG-FA method to reduce postoperative morbidity after esophagectomy.

custom-meta.meta-value: © Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2025

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Esophageal cancer ranks 8th cancer worldwide, and the 6th most deadly [1], with an increasing incidence in the last 20 years [2]. Squamous cell carcinoma represents 87% of cases but is decreasing whereas the incidence of adenocarcinoma is increasing, mainly in developed countries, due to gastro-intestinal reflux disease (GERD) [1]. Despite recent treatment improvement, mortality remains high with only 19% of 5-year survival between 2002 and 2008 versus 5% in 1975. [3] Whenever possible, surgical removal of the esophagus is the key treatment of this disease, often after neoadjuvant treatment [4]. Ivor Lewis esophagectomy, performed for tumors located of the lower or mid third esophagus, involves high morbimortality, mainly due to pulmonary and anastomotic complications, with a mortality rate of 1 to 9% and morbidity rate of 20 to 63% [5–7].

Minimally invasive surgery using laparoscopy decreases mortality rate (1,4%), length of hospital stay [8], and post-operative outcomes [9]. The most serious complication is esophagogastric anastomotic leakage (AL), occurring in 12% of cases and responsible of 40% of the post-operative mortality [10, 11]. Risk factors for AL include technical difficulties during anastomosis, tension, invaded resection margins, ASA score, diabetes, chronic renal failure, use of steroids, malnutrition, obesity, smoking, radiotherapy and surgery in a low volume center [12]. Yet the main risk factor is slow blood perfusion of the gastric tube. Blood perfusion can be assessed macroscopically by the surgeon, according to tissue color, bleeding and vessel pulsation, but this method lacks objectivity and precision. [2].

Indocyanine green fluorescence angiography (ICG-FA) helps to assess anastomotic tissue blood perfusion more accurately in digestive surgery. A near infrared camera shows ICG-FA tissue perfusion only seconds after injection [13]. Often used for colorectal surgery [14–18], it is also emerging in esophageal surgery, to assess blood perfusion of the gastric tube before esophagogastric anastomosis [19]. But most studies on the subject are small-size, retrospective and heterogenous. ICG-FA interpretation remains subjective and surgeon-dependent. To avoid this, recent Japanese studies have used a quantitative method, using the speed of tissue perfusion from the right gastroepiploic artery to the distal portion of the gastric tube. Koyanagi and al published a ROC curve of gastric tube perfusion speed, finding a cut-off speed of over 1.76 cm/s to significantly decrease AL (p = 0.004) [20].
Another method using fluorescence-intensity curves requires complex software and calculations, and there is no precise cut-off value. [19, 21].

An easy quantitative ICG-FA method time of blood perfusion from peripheral IV (intravenous) injection to the gastric tip. In a 2018 prospective cohort published by Kumagai and al. of 70 patients, anastomosis was made on tissue showing blood flow within 60 s after ICG injection, and non-perfused tissue after 90 s was resected. Rate of AL was low (1,4%) with mean gastric perfusion time of 35 s. Three AL occurred in tissue perfused after 60 s, whereas no AL occurred in tissue perfused within 60 s [22].

A 2017 retrospective cohort by Ohi and al. involving 120 patients showed decrease of AL rate when using ICG-FA with correction of poor perfusion within 60 s (1,7% versus 14,7%, HR 9 (p = 0.0098)). Based on literature, anastomosis on fully-perfused gastric tissue within 60 s after injecting ICG seems to be a reliable objective criteria to decrease AL rate after esophagectomy.
The aim of this study is to assess quantitative ICG-FA with a time-to-perfusion cut-off of 60 s after injection to reduce AL in Ivor Lewis esophagectomy at the Bordeaux University Hospital.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This “before and after” cohort study was conducted in the esogastric surgical department of the University Hospital in Bordeaux, France.

sec.title: Inclusion criteria
sec.p: All consecutive patients who underwent minimally invasive Ivor Lewis esophagectomy for a mid-low or gastroesophageal junction tumor, by laparoscopic and thoracoscopic approach with intrathoracic esophagogastric anastomosis, in our surgical department from 2018 to 2021 (with use of ICG-FA starting March 2020).

sec.title: Non-inclusion criteria
sec.p: Patients with cervical esophagogastric anastomosis, open surgery, pregnancy, age under 18, and missing data concerning the ICG-FA, were not included.

sec.title: ICG-FA protocol
sec.p:
After stapling of the gastric tube, 0,1 mg/kg of ICG was injected intravenously and flushed with 10 ml of 0,9%. NaCl. Gastric tube perfusion was assessed 60 s after injection using a SPY laparoscopic camera device (PINPOINT system), placed in the optical port. Images at 60 s (Image 1) and patient vital parameters were recorded. If ICG-FA did not reach the gastric tip within 60 s, the transition level was marked by a 3–0 PDS stitch (Image 2).Image 1
Satisfactory blood perfusion reaching the tip of the gastric tube. Oesogastric surgical department, Bordeaux University HospitalImage 2
Unsatisfactory blood perfusion of the tip of the gastric tube, with transition level identified by 3–0 PDS marking stitch. Oesogastric surgical department, Bordeaux University Hospital

End-to-side or end-to-end handsewn interrupted esophagogastric anastomosis was performed by a right axillary mini-thoracotomy. The gastric tip could be resected following macroscopic and ICG-FA perfusion assessment. Anastomosis was done at the level of the marking stitch, if possible, with recording of distances between gastric tip, marking stitch and anastomotic site.
Endoscopic or radiologic exams were performed when postoperative complications were suspected.

sec.title: Primary outcome
sec.p: The primary outcome was defined as AL stage 2 or 3 (requiring endoscopic or surgical treatment), within 30 days after surgery, diagnosed clinically (sepsis, mediastinitis, purulent discharge in drain), radiologically (leak of contrast product, air bubbles, abscess on CT scan with IV and ingested contrast product or upper gastro-intestinal series) or endoscopically (anastomotic opening, tissue defect or necrosis).
We recorded other postoperative outcomes including morbimortality, pulmonary complications, and length of stay.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Patients in the ICG-FA group were compared with the non ICG-FA group using a Chi- square test with a p value of less than 0.05 considered statistically significant.
Statistical analysis was performed using R software.

sec.title: Ethical approval
sec.p: Anonymized data was collected using computed patient files and the surgical department database. Our study was approved by the Bordeaux University Hospital Ethics Committee.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: 191 patients were included from January 2018 to March 2021. ICG-FA was used in 69 (36%) of patients. 1 patient was excluded because surgery was done by open approach to remove liver lesions.

sec.title: Patient baseline characteristics
sec.p:
Baseline characteristics (Table 1) were similar between the ICG-FA and non-ICG-FA groups, except for a higher BMI ≥ 25 in the ICG-FA group. 15% of patients were female, with a median age of 65 [IQR 59, 71]. Main risk factors for AL were similar between both groups, with mainly ASA score 2 patients (60%). Tumor characteristics were similar in both groups, with 87.8% of adenocarcinoma and 11.6% of squamous cell carcinoma. Median operative time was 300 min [IQR 270.00, 339.50], with a median blood loss of 200 ml [IQR 100.00, 300.00]. 17% of pathology reports revealed had invaded margins, and tumors were mostly TNM8 stage 3B (34.6%).Table 1

sec.title: Primary outcome
sec.p:
Rate of severe AL within 30 days was 8.4% (Table 2). There was no significant difference in AL between the groups, with 6 cases of AL (8.7%) in the ICG-FA group and 10 (8.2%) in the non-ICG-FA group. AL was mostly stage 3B (surgical revision without esophagostomy), in 5.8% and 5.7% of cases respectively.Table 2

sec.title: Secondary outcomes
sec.p: 30-day morbidity was 47.1% and 53.3% respectively (p = 0.502). The most frequent complications were pulmonary, occurring in 28 cases (40.6%) in the ICG-FA group and 59 cases (48.4%) in the non ICG-FA group (p = 0.376). There was no difference in postoperative outcomes between the groups, including pulmonary infection, acute respiratory distress syndrome, use of non-invasive ventilation, and length of ICU and hospital stay. However, hypoxemia rate was higher in the ICG-FA group (31.9% vs 16.4%, p = 0.021), as with atelectasis. No deaths within 30 days postoperatively were reported in the ICG-FA group, and one in the non-ICG-FA group due to aortoesophageal fistula.

sec.title: ICG-FA results and surgical strategy
sec.p:
ICG-FA findings and anastomosis characteristics are shown in Table 3. Contrary to heart-rate, median MAP during ICG-FA was higher when there resulted a change in surgical strategy after using ICG-FA (84.00 [IQR 76.50, 88.50] versus 74.50 [IQR 68.75, 80.50] (p = 0.012)). ICG-FA showed a transition level in 23 (33.8%) patients, with placing of a marking stitch in 19 (27.9%) patients. Anastomosis was done at this level or below in 60.8% of cases. Median length between gastric tip and marking stitch was 20 mm [IQR 0.00, 20.00] which is the standard distance for anastomosis in our practice. 4 patients had change in anastomotic site without gastric resection. 1 to 4 cm of the gastric tip was resected in 16 (23%) of ICG-FA patients, 2 patients during the abdominal approach and 14 patients during the thoracic approach, with no technical difficulties during ICG-FA or anastomosis. After gastric tip resection, 3 patients required an end-to-end anastomosis instead of end-to-side. In total, change in surgical strategy according to ICG-FA results occurred in 20 patients (29.9%), among which 2 patients presented with AL.Table 3

sec.title: ICG-FA results and postoperative outcomes
sec.p: 6 of the 69 ICG-FA patients presented with AL, with endoscopic treatment in one patient (stage 2), revision surgery without anastomotic dismounting in 3 patients (stage 3b), and by esophagostomy in one patient (stage 3a).

3 patients developed AL despite good tissue perfusion. 2 patients with stage 3a AL had poor macroscopic and ICG-FA perfusion, but which had been corrected by resection of the top 3 cm of the gastric tube. One patient had poor macroscopic and ICG-FA perfusion, with a marking stitch 4 cm below the gastric tip, but for technical reasons no change was made to the anastomotic site which was done 2 cm below the gastric tip. In this case AL at the gastric tip occurred at day 18 postoperatively, requiring endoscopic drainage.

Table 4 shows a subgroup analysis where postoperative outcomes were not different between patients with and without change in surgical strategy based on ICG-FA.Table 4

sec.title: Macroscopic and ICG-FA assessment of tissue perfusion
sec.p: 9 patients in the ICG-FA group showed good macroscopic tissue perfusion but ICG-FA was unsatisfactory. This led to change in strategy in 8 patients, with gastric tip resection in 7 patients and change of anastomotic site in one patient. None presented with AL.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Our cohort study comparing postoperative outcomes and change in surgical strategy before and after using ICG-FA during Ivor Lewis esophagectomy did not find statistically significant results. However, our 60-s threshold involved change in esophagogastric anastomotic site in one third of patients, without change in AL rate.

sec.title: ICG-FA and AL
sec.p: 6 patients presented with AL in the ICG-FA group. One patient with transition level had no change in surgical strategy, and AL may have been avoided. 3 patients with AL had satisfactory ICG-FA, but macroscopic tissue quality was also optimal, so there was no possibility to foresee AL. In these cases, AL may have been caused by factors other than ischemia, such as technical difficulties, inflammatory tissue, or anastomotic tension. 2 patients presented with AL despite resection of the gastric tip, but one leakage was at mid height of the gastric tube due to thermal injury, without necrosis, and could not have been prevented by ICG-FA.

Efforts were made to make the anastomosis on the marking stitch but this was not always possible due to insufficient gastric tube length, resulting in AL in one case where anastomosis was made 2 cm above the marking stitch. The other four patients with placement of anastomosis above the marking stitch did, however, not present AL.

Several studies suggest that surgical corrections according to ICG-FA can reduce AL. In a literature review with 1186 patients, Daele and al. found a significant decrease in AL from 20.5% to 9.9% when using ICG-FA (p < 0.001). When surgical correction was made after unsatisfactory ICG-FA (gastric resection, end-to-end anastomosis, vascular supercharge), AL rates were similar to that of the well-perfused patients (6,3%). Insufficient correction resulted in 47% of AL (p < 0.001) [2]. However, included studies were mainly retrospective and heterogenous. A more recent meta-analysis including 1399 patients, showing a global reduction in AL in the IGC group (RR 0.48; 95% CI 0.23–0.99; p = 0.05) [23].

The gastric tip being supplied by the microvascular mucosal and submucosal blood network [24], gastric ICG-FA interpretation is challenging, requiring fluorescence intensity or perfusion speed measurements. Koyanagi and al. found that AL was associated with ICG-FA speed but not with ICG-FA visualization of a complete gastro-epiploic arcade, suggesting microvascular perfusion is more predictive of AL [25]. A literature review by Koyanagi and al. found a 10% AL decrease with ICG-FA, however AL occurred in 24% of cases when poor ICG-FA was corrected, versus 43,1% without correction. This high AL rate despite correction may reflect poor microvascular perfusion and tissue quality.

ICG-FA can also be used during the thoracic approach [26–28], leaving time for the gastric tube to adjust to its permanent state after stapling, and assessing both gastric and esophageal anastomotic tissue. A study by Thammineedi and al. witnessed additional esophageal resection in 5 out of 13 patients after ICG-FA, avoiding possible AL caused by esophageal ischemia after lymphadenectomy [29].

Sakuma and al. evaluated correlation between ICG-FA results and endoscopic results at postoperative day 1 in 86 patients. Their only significant correlation was between ICG-FA results and congestive mucosa in endoscopy, which suggests that ICG-FA may be a better indicator of veinous congestion rather than poor arterial blood supply [30].
Our AL rate was relatively low (8,4%), and reduction of this rate, even with use of ICG-FA, is difficult to achieve. This may explain our non-significant results.
ICG-FA and other measures such as preoperative nutrition may contribute to the aggregation of marginal gains, for incremental reduction of anastomotic leak.

sec.title: Quantitative use of ICG-FA
sec.p: Our 60-s threshold was chosen according to literature [13, 22, 31–33]. This was a simple, reproductive technique. Several studies have used the 60-s rule to choose anastomotic site, enabling a decrease in AL from 10 to 1%, p = 0.009 [34] and 8.6% to 5.9% [35].

In Kumagai and al’s “90-s-rule” study [22] anastomosis was done on tissue perfused within 60 s whenever possible, and tissue perfused after 90 s was resected. 30% of conduits were well perfused under 60 s. Mean time-to-perfusion was 35 s, with 1 AL among 3 cases where the anastomosis was done on tissue perfused after 60 s [22]. Noma and al used a 30-s threshold [32], with use of corrective measures such as gastric resection, mobilization or supercharge on tissue perfused > 30 s. This reduced AL with Dindo-Clavien ≥ 2 (OR 0,24). Other cohorts found thresholds of 98 s (Specificity 98%, p = 0,147) [36] and 36 s [37] as predictive of AL, suggesting time to-perfusion measurements are associated with postoperative outcomes. However, our choice of 60 s may induce longer gastric tip resection, increasing anastomotic tension, and in 3 cases end-to-end anastomosis was made to avoid this.

Yamamoto and al. conducted a retrospective review of 97 cases, with 12 postoperative leakages. The ICG-FA videos enabled creation of time-intensity curves, showing a trend towards slower intensity in the cases with anastomotic leakage. However these results were not significant [38].

Several software tools are emerging to enable a better, objective use of ICG-FA, as shown by Nijssen and al. who compared two different software algorithms, using fluorescence time curves. However, this study showed differences in measurement (mean relative difference + 58.2%), without significant relationship with AL. This underlines the extent of the technical possibilities of IGC use, but with a lack in standardization making its interpretation difficult [39].

sec.title: Strengths
sec.p: Our study has methodological strength as it was conducted in a high-volume center, with standardized surgical technique. Our ICG-FA protocol is simple, precise and easy to use in common surgical practice.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: Our study was not randomized, however both study groups had similar characteristics. Absence of randomization also provides real-world data with better external validity. Our « before and after» cohort design induces historical bias, as therapeutic care improves over time, reducing postoperative morbidity. We therefore included patients since 2018, after our unit had 3 years of experience in minimally invasive surgery. Furthermore, despite ICG-FA results, choice of anastomotic site was left to the surgeon’s discretion. Poor ICG-FA was not corrected in 13% of cases, reflecting real-life situations.

sec.title: Perspectives
sec.p: Large, randomized studies are needed to confirm these retrospective results, exploring different quantitative ICG-FA measures such as colorimetric measurements [16], or fluorescence time-intensity curves [19, 21, 40, 41]. Artificial intelligence may also help with interpretation of results [42]. Poor ICG-FA results can also enable specific monitoring of patients considered at higher risk of AL [36].

It is also questionable whether IGC-FA is the best method to assess gastric perfusion, as shown by Haruta and al. who compared ICG-FA and multispectral camera on 30 cases. ICG-FA was assessed quantitively as time in luminance increase. AL occurred in 100% of patients considered with poor vascularization in multispectral camera, versus 60% with poor ICG-FA results [43].

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Our quantitative ICG-FA protocol influenced our decision of anastomotic site during minimally invasive Ivor Lewis, but has not led to significant reduction in AL rate when applied in a center with a low AL rate (8,4%). Therefore, the use of ICG-FA does not diminish AL rate in high-volume, specialized centers with AL rates within international benchmarks. Further studies may help determine whether ICG-FA proves more useful in low-volume centers.

fn.p: Springer Nature remains neutral with regard to jurisdictional claims in published maps and institutional affiliations.

notes.title: Author contributions
notes.p: LD, CG, and DC contributed to the study conception and design, LD and FP contributed to data acquisition, YB contributed to the data analysis, and LD wrote the manuscript and prepared the tables and figures. CG, DC and YB reviewed the manuscript.

notes.title: Data availability
notes.p: No datasets were generated or analysed during the current study.

notes.title: Ethical requirements
notes.p: Approved by Bordeaux University Hospital Ethics Committee.

notes.title: Competing interests
